intro: Ocimum pyramidatum, commonly known as holy basil or tulsi, is a aromatic herb native to the Indian subcontinent. It is a member of the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its opposite, oval-shaped leaves and small, tubular flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with a spreading habit and branched stems. Its leaves are rich in essential oils, containing compounds like eugenol and cineole, which contribute to its medicinal and aromatic properties. Ocimum pyramidatum is widely cultivated for use in traditional medicine, religious rituals, and as a culinary herb.
